free_txt: BP
Compiler's comment: Ra-Be neutron spectrum is below
13 MeV.
A steel Geiger-Muller counter of dimensions
3.7 cm x 12 cm with a wall thickness of 0.20 mm and
filled with argon to a pressure of 15 cm Hg was
surrounded with a lead foil (1.0 g/cm2).
Probable errors.
The source of neutrons (Be+200 mg Ra).
The absorbing cylinders used in these experiments
were 17.8 cm long and approximately 10 cm in diameter.
Compiler's comment: calculated as 4.1cm x 1.3 g/cm3.
Transmission is normally smaller than 1 (or only
slightly bigger when an error of suitable size is
given, or when it is raw data), but here we have
values bigger than 1, authors explain it by saying
that fast neutrons slowed down in the absorbers may
result in more neutrons coming out. This means
something like a (n,2n) reaction in the absorber.
The absorption of fast neutrons has been
measured with cylindrical absorbers to minimize the
loss of neutrons by scattering and with a method of
detection which made any change in the energy
spectrum of the fast neutrons relatively unimportant.
The fast neutrons were detected by slowing them in
5.7 cm of paraffin at 8 and counting by means of a
Geiger-Muller counter the gamma-rays produced by the
absorption of these slow neutrons in cadmium and lead.
Table I, page 411.

measured with cylindrical absorbers to minimize the

Table I, page 411.
Transmission is normally smaller than 1 (or only
slightly bigger when an error of suitable size is
given, or when it is raw data), but here we have
values bigger than 1, authors explain it by saying
that fast neutrons slowed down in the absorbers may
result in more neutrons coming out. This means
something like a (n,2n) reaction in the absorber.
Measurements were made alternately with and
without cylindrical absorbers. The counts recorded by
the Geiger-Muller counter (after subtracting the
natura1 background) were due chiefly to gamma-rays
excited in the lead by fast neutrons. When the
cylindrical "absorbers" were placed around the source,
a marked decrease in the counting rate was observed.
In order to show that these effects did not arise
solely from changes, the counter was removed from its
lead housing and placed in a copper cylinder of 2.8
cm wall thickness. Average value Pb and Cu gamma-rays
detection.
Calculated thickness as 4.1cm x 1.3 g/cm3=5.33 g/cm2.
